Sentences: January 25, 2012  CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Good afternoon and welcome.
Speaker: None

Sentences: In my opening remarks I will briefly review today’s policy decision by the Federal Open Market Committee.
Speaker: None

Sentences: And then I’ll discuss next the consensus statement that has been distributed to you regarding the Committee’s longer-run policy goals and strategy.
Speaker: None

Sentences: And finally, I’ll place today’s policy decision in the context of our economic projections and our assessments of the appropriate path of monetary policy.
Speaker: None

Sentences: And I’ll then, of course, be glad to take your questions.
Speaker: None

Sentences: As indicated in the statement released earlier this afternoon, to support a stronger economic recovery and to help ensure that inflation, over time, is at levels consistent with our statutory mandate, the Committee expects to maintain a highly accommodative stance for monetary policy.
Speaker: None

Sentences: In particular, the Committee decided to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to ¼ percent and currently anticipates that economic conditions are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels for the federal funds rate at least until late 2014.
Speaker: None

Sentences: To provide support for the recovery in the context of price stability, the Committee will also continue the program that we announced in September to extend the average maturity of the Federal Reserve’s holdings of securities.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Following careful deliberations, Committee participants have reached broad agreement on a statement that sets forth our longer-run goals and policy strategy.
Speaker: None

Sentences: This statement should not be interpreted as indicating any change in how the Federal Reserve conducts monetary policy.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Rather, its purpose is to increase the transparency and predictability of policy.
Speaker: None

Sentences: There is today widespread agreement that clear and transparent central bank communications facilitate uncertainty, increase the effectiveness of monetary policy, and enhance accountability to the public.
Speaker: None

Sentences: The statement begins by noting the Committee’s firm commitment to fulfill our statutory mandate of promoting maximum employment, stable prices, and moderate long-term interest rates.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Since monetary policy actions tend to influence economic activity and prices with a lag, our decisions appropriately reflect the Committee’s longer-run goals, our medium-term outlook, and our assessment of the balance of risks, including risks to the financial system that could impede the attainment of our goals.
Speaker: None

Sentences: An important aspect of policy transparency is clarity about policy objectives.
Speaker: None

Sentences: With respect to the objective of price stability, it is essential to recognize that the inflation rate over the longer run is primarily determined by monetary policy, and hence the Committee has the ability to specify a longer-run goal for inflation.
Speaker: None

Sentences: The Committee judges that inflation at the rate of 2 percent, as measured by the annual change in the price index for personal consumption expenditures, is most consistent over the longer run with our statutory mandate.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Over time, a higher inflation rate would reduce the public’s ability to make accurate longer-term economic and financial decisions, whereas a lower inflation rate would be associated with an elevated probability of falling into deflation, which can lead to significant economic problems.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Clearly communicating to the public this 2 percent goal for inflation over the longer run should help foster price stability and moderate long-term interest rates and will enhance the Committee’s ability to promote maximum employment in the face of significant economic disturbances.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Maximum employment stands on an equal footing with price stability as an objective of monetary policy.
Speaker: None

Sentences: A difference with price stability is that the maximum level of employment in a dynamics of the labor market, including demographic trends, the pace of technological innovation, and a variety of other influences, including a range of economic policies.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Because monetary policy does not determine the maximum level of employment that the economy can sustain in the longer term, and since many of the determinants of maximum employment may change over time or may not be directly measurable, it is not feasible for any central bank to specify a fixed goal for the longer-run level of employment.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Although the Committee cannot freely choose a longer-run goal for employment, it can estimate the level of maximum employment and use that estimate to inform its policy decisions.
Speaker: None

Sentences: The Committee considers a wide range of indicators in making its assessments of maximum employment, recognizing that such assessments are necessarily uncertain and subject to revision over time.
Speaker: None

Sentences: For example, in the latest set of projections that have been distributed to you, Committee participants’ estimates of the longer-run normal rate of unemployment have a central tendency of 5.2 percent to 6.0 percent—roughly unchanged from last January but higher than the corresponding interval several years ago.
Speaker: None

Sentences: As I noted, the level of maximum employment is not immutable; in particular, it could be increased by effective policies, such as education and training that improve workforce skills.
Speaker: None

Sentences: If the Committee’s assessments pointed to an increase in the maximum attainable level of employment, our policy strategy would be modified appropriately to aim at the higher level.
Speaker: None

Sentences: In setting monetary policy, the Committee seeks to mitigate deviations of inflation from its mandate-consistent rate and deviations of employment from our assessments of its maximum level.
Speaker: None

Sentences: These dual objectives are generally complementary.
Speaker: None

Sentences: For example, under present circumstances, in which the unemployment rate is elevated and the inflation outlook is subdued, consistent with promoting both objectives.
Speaker: None

Sentences: And in the longer term, low and stable inflation can help promote healthy growth in output and employment.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Of course, circumstances may sometimes arise in which the dual objectives are not complementary.
Speaker: None

Sentences: In such cases, the Committee follows a balanced approach in promoting these two objectives, taking into account the magnitude of the deviations and potentially different time horizons over which inflation and employment are projected to return to levels judged consistent with our mandate.
Speaker: None

Sentences: In other words, the Committee always treats its primary objectives of price stability and maximum employment symmetrically, and the stance of policy at any given time is determined by the size, social cost, and expected evolution of the deviations of each of the Committee’s policy objectives from its desired level.
Speaker: None

Sentences: I will now turn to the economic projections of the 17 FOMC participants—that is, 5 Board members and 12 Reserve Bank presidents—submitted in conjunction with today’s meeting.
Speaker: None

Sentences: The central tendencies and ranges of those projections for the years 2011 to 2014 and over the longer run are depicted in the figures that have been distributed.
Speaker: None

Sentences: The longer-run projections—shown at the right of each figure—represent participants’ assessments of the rate to which each variable will converge over time under appropriate monetary policy and in the absence of further shocks to the economy.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Incoming information suggests that the economy has been expanding moderately, notwithstanding some slowing in global growth.
Speaker: None

Sentences: The Committee expects the pace of economic growth to be, over coming quarters—to be moderate over coming quarters, reflecting ongoing drags from the housing sector and still-tight credit conditions for many households and smaller product in 2012 have a central tendency of 2.2 to 2.7 percent.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Strains in global financial markets continue to pose significant downside risks to that outlook.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Looking further ahead, economic activity is expected to accelerate gradually in conjunction with strengthening consumer and business confidence, improving financial conditions, and the continuation of a highly accommodative stance for monetary policy.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Specifically, participants’ GDP projections for 2013 have a central tendency of 2.8 to 3.2 percent, and their projections for 2014 have a central tendency of 3.3 to 4.0 percent, noticeably higher than the central tendency of 2.3 to 2.6 percent for their longer-run growth projections.
Speaker: None

Sentences: A number of recent indicators point to some further improvement in overall labor market conditions, but the unemployment rate remains elevated.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Moreover, in light of the anticipated modest pace of economic recovery, the Committee expects that over coming quarters the unemployment rate will decline only gradually toward its mandate-consistent levels.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Indeed, participants’ projections for the unemployment rate in the fourth quarter of this year have a central tendency of 8.2 to 8.5 percent that is little different from the latest monthly reading of 8.5 percent.
Speaker: None

Sentences: With economic growth expected to pick up somewhat over time, the unemployment rate is expected to decline to 6.7 to 7.6 percent by the fourth quarter of 2014—still well above participants’ estimates of the longer-run normal rate of unemployment.
Speaker: None

Sentences: I’ll turn now to the outlook for inflation.
Speaker: None

Sentences: The prices of oil and other commodities have generally flattened out or turned downward over the past couple of quarters, while low levels of resource utilization have continued to constrain the growth of labor costs.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Consequently, consumer price inflation—which surged in the first half of last year—has been subdued in recent expectations have remained stable.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Over coming quarters, the Committee anticipates that inflation will run at or below levels consistent with the mandate-consistent rate of 2 percent.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Specifically, participants’ inflation projections have a central tendency of 1.4 to 1.8 percent for 2012 and remain subdued at around 1½ to 2 percent through 2014.
Speaker: None

Sentences: As a further step in enhancing the clarity of our communications, the Committee recently decided to begin publishing information about participants’ assessments of appropriate monetary policy—that is, the path of policy that each participant judges as most likely to foster mandate-consistent outcomes for employment and inflation if the economy evolves as expected.
Speaker: None

Sentences: These judgments about future policy underlie the participants’ projections of growth, unemployment, and inflation that I just described.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Rather—excuse me—Importantly, these policy assessments should not be viewed as unconditional pledges.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Rather, just as with our economic projections, these policy projections reflect the information available at the time of the forecast and are subject to future revision in light of evolving economic and financial conditions.
Speaker: None

Sentences: In the chart labeled “Appropriate Timing of Policy Firming,” each shaded bar indicates the number of Committee participants who judge that the initial increase in the target federal funds rate would appropriately occur in the specified calendar year shown below the bar.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Six participants anticipate that policy firming is likely to commence in 2015 or 2016, while five others expect policy firming to commence in 2014.
Speaker: None

Sentences: The remaining six participants judge that policy liftoff would be appropriate in 2012 or 2013.
Speaker: None

Sentences: More detail is provided by the chart labeled “Appropriate Pace of Policy Firming.”  In that chart, the dots depict the distribution of participants’ assessments regarding the appropriate level of the target federal funds rate at the end of each of the next several years and over the appropriate federal funds rate at the end of 2014 will be at or below 1 percent, while 6 participants anticipate higher rates at that time.
Speaker: None

Sentences: In effect, those judgments are reflected in today’s meeting statement, in which the Committee indicated that economic conditions “are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels for the federal funds rate at least through late 2014.”   As I have noted, we are also proceeding with the program that we announced in September to extend the average maturity of the Federal Reserve’s holding of securities, thereby fostering more accommodative financial conditions without changing the overall size of the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet.
Speaker: None

Sentences: The Committee regularly reviews the size and composition of our securities holdings, and we will adjust those holdings as appropriate.
Speaker: None

Sentences: In particular, the Committee recognizes the hardships imposed by high and persistent unemployment and an underperforming economy, and it is prepared to provide further monetary accommodation if employment is not making sufficient progress toward our assessments of its maximum level or if inflation shows signs of moving further below its mandate-consistent rate.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Thank you for your patience.
Speaker: None

Sentences: I’ll be happy to take your questions.
Speaker: None

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Steve Liesman, CNBC.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, we’ve had several months of economic data that’s been stronger than most forecasters expected—employment was over 200,000, the unemployment rate’s come down to 8½ percent—but there seems to be very little mention of this recent strength in the statement.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Do you and the Committee, Mr. Chairman, harbor doubts about the recent strength in the economy?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: And are you and the Committee baking in additional quantitative easing in order to achieve the growth rates that you’ve even forecast here?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Steve, there’s certainly been some encouraging news improved, industrial production has been relatively strong—so there are some positive signs, no doubt.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: At the same time, we’ve had mixed results in some other areas, such as retail sales, and we continue to see headwinds emanating from Europe, coming from the slowing global economy and some other factors as well.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, you know, we are obviously hoping that the strength we saw in the fourth quarter and in recent data will continue into 2012, but we’re going to continue to monitor that situation.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I don’t think we’re ready to declare that we’ve entered a new, stronger phase at this point; we’ll continue to look at the data.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We will, as I’ve said in my statement, and as we have in fact in the FOMC statement, you know, we continue to review our holdings—our portfolio holdings, securities, and we are prepared to take further steps in that direction if we see that the recovery’s faltering or if inflation is not moving toward target.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So that’s something—that’s an option that’s certainly on the table.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I think it would be premature to say definitively one way or the other, but we continue to look at that option, and if conditions warrant, we will certainly consider using it.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: I’m a little confused by these forecasts.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: I was hoping you could sort of help me understand what we’re looking at.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: It seems to say that you expect that at the end of 2014, unemployment will be at or above 7 percent, inflation will be at or below 2 percent—and yet 11 of the 17 members of your Committee think that will be a good moment to start raising interest rates again.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: If unemployment and inflation are in fact symmetric objectives for the Fed, how can that possibly be the case?
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: And is there any tolerance for above-trend inflation in the service of catch-up growth?
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentences: Well, let me first observe that we have in fact, of course, been very accommodative in the last couple of years.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We’ve kept interest rates close to zero, the period over which we expect to see rates very low, and our maturity extension program is still ongoing, so we maintain a quite accommodative path of policy at this point.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I would further say that I think it’s important to emphasize that we’re not going to mechanically take the interest rate projections that participants provide and just build policy off of that.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I mean, it’s still going to be necessary for the Committee to exercise collective judgment, to consider the costs and risks of additional policy actions, to discuss the uncertainty about the forecast and other factors that come into the policy decision.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Now, all that being said, if inflation is going to remain below target for an extended period, and unemployment progress is very slow, then I think your implicit question is right, there is a case for additional policy action, and we’ll—you know, we want to continue to observe the situation, but we’re certainly prepared to look for different ways to provide support to the economy if, in fact, we have this unsatisfactory situation.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Hi, Mr. Chairman, Craig Torres from Bloomberg News.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentences: Congrats on the inflation target, or goal—that’s a big achievement for you, I’m sure.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentences: I’d like to ask if you could explain a little bit the way you think inflation is now working in the economy.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentences: The 2012 central tendency is kind of low, and along with that question, I’d like to know where you think full employment is in the near term, like the next year or two, given the structural impediments that many Fed officials have been talking about.
Speaker: CRAIG TORRES.

Sentences: Well, there are a number of factors that make us expect inflation to be quite low in the next couple of years.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Certainly, we are seeing a reversal, or at least a flattening out, of the commodity price increases that caused headline inflation to rise earlier in 2011.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And the futures markets, and our own estimates of supply and demand globally with the slowing global economy, suggest that most likely—although, of course, there’s a lot of On top of that, of course, we have a very high rate of unemployment; pressure on wages is quite restrained.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And putting that together with strong productivity gains, the costs of production—unit labor costs—are growing very slowly.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Expectations of inflation seem well anchored and, in fact, have been on the low side relative to recent history in recent months.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So for all those reasons, inflation looks to be at or modestly below the 2 percent target going forward.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: With respect to the maximum employment measure, we provided a—we have been providing, in fact, for four years, as long as we’ve been providing the economic projections—an estimate of the long-run sustainable rate of unemployment, which is currently—the central tendency is currently 5.2 to 6 percent.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That is higher than it was a couple of years ago, reflecting structural impediments and other changes.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We’re concerned that the large amount of long-term unemployment may be causing some workers to lose skills or lose labor force attachment, which, at least for a while, will also likely increase the so-called natural rate, or sustainable rate, of unemployment.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So there are a number of factors working in that direction.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But in any case, while there’s certainly a lot of uncertainty about exactly where the natural rate of unemployment is, clearly, at 8½ percent, I think we’re comfortably above anybody’s estimate, and for that reason, we still consider the labor market to be obviously quite slack.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: Jon Hilsenrath from the Wall Street Journal.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, how much confidence do you have in the FOMC’s ability to forecast the economy and inflation out three years?
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: And consequently, how much confidence do you have in the interest rate projections that the Fed has made public today, particularly the ones that go out to 2014 and beyond?
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: And if I may add a follow-up to that, there seems to be an asymmetry in these Chairman.
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: So when we look at these projections, are we really seeing the most likely expected path of interest rates because the Chairman’s view isn’t represented exclusively here?
Speaker: JON HILSENRATH.

Sentences: Well, your first question—our ability to forecast three and four years out is obviously very limited, there’s no question about that.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Nevertheless, we have to make a best guess, a provisional plan, in the same way that a firm making an investment has to make a best guess or provisional plan about where the economy and the industry is going to be over a number of years.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And so it’s certainly possible that we will be either too optimistic or too pessimistic, in which case we’ll have to adjust both our forecasts and our policy expectations.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That being said, you know, currently, the zero lower bound on policy rates—at least according to many estimates—is still binding; that is, even if the economy were a bit stronger, the very low interest rates we currently have would still be valid, still be appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And so for that reason, unless there’s a substantial strengthening of the economy in the near term, I would think that it’s a pretty good guess that we will be keeping rates low for some time from now.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We don’t identify the specific individuals who provide the projections.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Among other reasons, we want to make sure that people come to the meeting willing to talk and not be wedded to a specific position, and that’s why, again, the Committee makes a collective decision after using as input these projections, which are circulated to all the members of the Committee before the meeting so that they can see what their colleagues believe.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: As far as what individual members do believe, we certainly have other vehicles for expressing our views.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: All of us give speeches, all of us give interviews and are—you know, I give frequent testimony, so there are plenty of opportunities to get a sense of what individual members believe.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But again, we felt that this information, which presents both the diversity of views in the Committee but also shows where Chairman’s term is not infinite and at some point there’ll be a new Chairman, but there’s a lot more continuity on the FOMC collectively.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The average Bank president is on the FOMC for as much as 10 years and Governors’ terms are 14 years.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So even as the Chairman changes, much of the FOMC remains continuous.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, as we talk about interest rates in 2014, the fact that there is quite wide-ranging agreement that interest rates will be low for a long time, should give you more confidence that that’s not dependent on a single individual.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Greg Ip of the Economist.
Speaker: GREG IP.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, the Fed’s statutory goals are price stability and maximum employment, but traditionally the Fed has interpreted that somewhat flexibly in the sense that if there was a conflict between the two, they would push for price stability rather than for full employment on the view that over time, stable prices was the best contribution monetary policy could make to maximum employment.
Speaker: GREG IP.

Sentences: But today you went to some pains to say that, actually, you treat these goals—put them on an equal footing, and that there might be circumstances in which you put one above the other.
Speaker: GREG IP.

Sentences: So following up a little bit on Binyamin’s question, do I take it that if inflation were to move somewhat above your 2 percent preferred level, that you would tolerate that in order to make further progress on unemployment?
Speaker: GREG IP.

Sentences: Well, the period of time, yes, we treat them symmetrically.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We cannot control, of course, where inflation and unemployment are at each moment in time, and so there will be periods when, for reasons outside of our control, inflation and unemployment will move away from their desired levels.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: If—In those situations, the speed at which—I think “tolerate” might be too strong of a word, because we always want to get everything, both sides of the mandate, back to their desired levels—but the speed at which we example, if inflation did go above target by a modest amount, we would certainly try to get it back down to target, but if unemployment were very high, that would lead us to be more cautious and slower in returning to target.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So that’s why “medium term”—which is, these targets are all medium term—is a flexible concept, and it depends on the initial conditions, how far away the two key variables are from their objectives at the beginning of the process.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Greg Robb, MarketWatch.
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, thank you.
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentences: You haven’t had a very good time in all the Republican presidential debates, and I was wondering if I could have your comment on what you’ve heard.
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentences: And some of the analysts I talked to said that one of the reasons for this hostility, perhaps, is that a lot of the Republican primary voters are on fixed incomes and have an inability to invest and make money with their funds.
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentences: So could you talk to them as well?
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentences: And one more thing, if Republicans take back the White House in November and ask you to resign, would you?
Speaker: GREG ROBB.

Sentences: So I’m not going to get involved in political rhetoric.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I’m just going to stay completely away from that.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I have a job to do, and as long as I’m here, I will do everything I can to help the Federal Reserve achieve its dual mandate of price stability and maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That’s my answer to the last part as well.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I’m not going to be thinking about hypothetical situations in the future.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In the case of savers, you know, we think about all these issues, and we certainly recognize that the low interest rates that we’re using to try to stimulate investment and expansion of the economy also impose a cost on savers who have a lower return.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And we do hear about that, obviously, and we do think about that.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I guess the response I would make is that the savers in our economy are dependent on a healthy economy in order to get adequate returns.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In particular, people own stocks and corporate bonds and other they are not going to get good returns on those investments.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So I think what we need to do, as is often the case when the economy goes into a very weak situation, then low interest rates are needed to help restore the economy to something closer to full employment and to increase growth and that, in turn, will lead ultimately to higher returns across all assets for savers and investors.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So that’s—I think that’s how we would explain it.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But again, you know, we recognize that during periods like this, savers are getting a lower return.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: One reason why it’s extremely important for us to maintain price stability, of course, is that at least that minimizes any losses due to inflation that savers might suffer.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Hi, Chairman.
Speaker: DONNA BORAK.

Sentences: Donna Borak of American Banker.
Speaker: DONNA BORAK.

Sentences: Shifting a little bit, I’d like to take a look back to the rules that the Fed released back in late December.
Speaker: DONNA BORAK.

Sentences: Obviously, it was a mammoth task for Fed staff to put forth, and considered the heart of  Dodd–Frank.
Speaker: DONNA BORAK.

Sentences: There were certain provisions that were left out, including the liquidity requirements, due largely to the fact that there’s global consensus needed on those rules in the Basel III process.
Speaker: DONNA BORAK.

Sentences: But I was hoping you could expand a little bit more on the decision for Fed staff to forgo specifying what the additional capital requirements would be for those banks that were not necessarily deemed GSIBs, at least now, but were still above the $50 billion threshold, and to talk a little bit about what the core issues are in deciding whether or not that additional capital should come in the form of a surcharge, what that surcharge might look like, and when we might know.
Speaker: DONNA BORAK.

Sentences: Well, you’re referring, I think, to the 165–166 rules, which will focus on the supervisory oversight of the largest banks.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: It’s a very big and complicated rule, as everyone knows, and so our position at this time is that we would still like to get feedback questions, and we’ll be considering those during the comment period and after, as we put together a rule.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The notion of the surcharges is that banks which do not pose significant threats to the systemic stability of Unites States, you know, should not have a significant surcharge.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We’re required to consider these issues by Dodd–Frank, but our view is that it’s the largest banks, the ones whose failure would endanger our financial system, that should be subject to these surcharges because, first—because we need to have them be safer than smaller banks, and secondly, because we want to try to equalize the cost of credit that they face.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In other words, a bank which is thought to be too big to fail gets an artificial subsidy in the interest rate that it can borrow at, and by having additional capital requirements, that tends to equalize the cost of funding to different banks and reduces the incentive of banks to get large just to create the impression of being too big to fail.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So we think those are important and we will continue to work with them.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The Basel Committee has provided some sense of the range of what those surcharges will fall into, and so we’re still working on defining exactly the criteria, but you can assume that it will be a fairly continuous range between the $50 billion banks and the very largest banks in our economy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: As I said, we’re getting reactions and comments.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We hope to get—you know, early this year—we hope to come back with a clarification on the rule, and of course, we’re also working hard on implementing Basel III itself, which we want to do during 2012—we want to put out the rule during 2012.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Mark Felsenthal with Reuters.
Speaker: MARK FELSENTHAL.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, for more than three years now, the Fed has conducted policy through extraordinary means, and yet the new information that we have today pertains mostly to an eventual tightening of policy through and what should anybody looking at your communications today deduce about an eventual expansion of the balance sheet through more asset purchases?
Speaker: MARK FELSENTHAL.

Sentences: So we will be providing, in our minutes and in our Survey of Economic Projections, which will be released in three weeks—we’ll be providing some additional qualitative information about peoples’—participants’ views of the balance sheet going forward.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The reason that I can’t provide all that information now is basically that we received, you know, a whole range of qualitative comments, and we had further discussion during the meeting yesterday and today, and so, you know, we’re going to need a little time to summarize that and to have it approved by, you know—the minutes, of course, and the SEP are approved by the entire Committee—and so, in that respect, it will be a definitive statement about what we currently know about the balance sheet.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I can say a few things.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: You know, one is that it certainly remains—expanding the balance sheet certainly remains an option, one that we would consider very seriously if—in particular, if progress toward full employment was continued, or it became more, inadequate, or if inflation remained exceptionally low.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So we’ll continue to look at that.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: As we say in our statement, we’re prepared to take additional measures in general, and that would be certainly one class of measures we would want to consider.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I can make one additional point, which maybe wasn’t obvious, which is that, in June, we provided some principles relating the sales of assets—ultimate sales of assets—to the path of interest rates, and those remain—those principles remain in force.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And so one implication of our extension of our expected point of takeoff to late 2014 is to imply that the initial sales from our balance sheet, which again are far down the road but—that begins—that will be later than previously thought.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That will be presumably in 2015.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So we do expect to hold our balance sheet at a high level for a are still debating, and it will depend both on our assessment of the efficacy and the risks of that particular tool, but also of how the economy is evolving.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Robin Harding from the Financial Times.
Speaker: ROBIN HARDING.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, when I look at these forecasts for 2014, the median of the forecast is, I think, 0.75 and the mean is 1.12 percent.
Speaker: ROBIN HARDING.

Sentences: If I were to draw a line through this—these dots, how should I draw it so I best understand what the FOMC is most likely to do?
Speaker: ROBIN HARDING.

Sentences: And the second part—in the minutes, you say that the Committee will consider further options for improvements to the SEP, the economic projections.
Speaker: ROBIN HARDING.

Sentences: Could you tell us a bit more about what further you might do?
Speaker: ROBIN HARDING.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: ROBIN HARDING.

Sentences: Well, again, first I want to emphasize that there is no mechanical relationship between these projections and the outcomes of the FOMC decisions.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Of course, they’re a big input into those decisions, but it’s a collective decision.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: If you want to draw lines, I guess I would—I guess my suggestion would be to look at the median, the middle of the distribution, because we do have a democratic process in the Committee, and so the median would give you some sense of where the weight balances against higher—in favor of higher or lower rates.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Again, we did note that in support of our assessment of late 2014, which is a Committee decision, and of course there was a 9-to-1 vote in favor of that, but that is supported by the observation that 11 of the 17 participants expect the funds rate at the end of 2014 to be 1 percent or less, and so presumably the takeoff would not be much earlier than that.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In terms of future additions, there are a lot of ways we could go.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We could provide, for example, more relationships between—more information about the relationship between individuals’ policy preferences and their forecasts, and so on.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But there’s nothing specific now that has been decided.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We have a very capable subcommittee, which is charged with continual assessment and possibilities, and we would welcome feedback for that matter.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But there’s nothing specific planned at this point.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Derek Kravitz, Associated Press.
Speaker: DEREK KRAVITZ.

Sentences: Last night the President unveiled a plan to revamp and expand the government’s refinancing program.
Speaker: DEREK KRAVITZ.

Sentences: Essentially, the Fed released a white paper earlier this month that said that up to 2½ million homeowners could benefit from this, essentially save $3,000 per year in mortgage payments.
Speaker: DEREK KRAVITZ.

Sentences: Right now there’s a mortgage settlement being brokered between state attorneys general and the nation’s major mortgage lenders, something to the tune of $25 billion, much of which would be in the form of principal reduction.
Speaker: DEREK KRAVITZ.

Sentences: In the white paper that was released earlier this month, the Fed seemed to indicate that principal reduction could be helpful, but it was unclear about whether they thought that this was an acceptable or even feasible option.
Speaker: DEREK KRAVITZ.

Sentences: They also made clear that a lot of the proposals that are currently out there “eat around the edges,” so to speak, when you’re dealing with a foreclosure crisis, and a lot of economists agree.
Speaker: DEREK KRAVITZ.

Sentences: Do you think a principal reduction in the form of the major mortgage settlement would do a lot to help the housing crisis?
Speaker: DEREK KRAVITZ.

Sentences: And if not, is there any other alternative proposal that would help?
Speaker: DEREK KRAVITZ.

Sentences: Well, the Federal Reserve obviously has a very strong interest in the housing sector.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The weakness of the housing sector is an important reason why the economy is not recovering more robustly, and the problems in housing finance are part of the reason why monetary policy has not been more powerful—because part of our transmission mechanism is through lower interest rates, which affects refinancing; it affects sales and purchases as well.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, in addition to that, as bank supervisors, we have considerable interest in servicing, in loan modifications, in delinquencies, and all the aspects of mortgage lending.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So at a number of issues, including refinancing and mortgage finance.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I think it’s important to say that our intent in that white paper was to provide the benefit of our analysis to the public and to those who will be making policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We did not take specific stands on individual issues.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: What we tried to do was provide the pros and the cons and provide some context for these debates.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So we did discuss refinancing, we did discuss principal forgiveness.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I would say that there’s a variety of views about principal forgiveness within the Federal Reserve System, and there is no official position.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: There—It seems very likely that principal forgiveness could be helpful, depending on how it’s structured, in reducing delinquencies.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: There are also some potential drawbacks; one of them is the fact that the amount of negative equity in the United States is about $700 billion, which is enormous, and so there is no conceivable program that is going to put everybody in the country above water.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And so I think the issue then becomes, if we have $20 or $25 billion or whatever the number may end up being in this settlement, you know, what is the most cost-effective way to help as many people as possible?
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And I think that’s an ongoing debate.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But with respect to principal reduction, you know, I’ve spoken about this in the past, and it certainly has some advantages; a lot depends on how it’s structured, and a lot depends on what the alternatives are that you’re considering.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: Peter Barnes of FOX Business.
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: One of the goals of the Fed and the release of all these new materials, the forecast, and the policy announcement are to help to create expectations and set expectations.
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: But are you concerned at all that this—that the materials and the forecasts and the policy announcement path today might help create negative expectations?
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: In other words, the average American’s takeaway of your announcement to keep interest rates low—exceptionally low, through 2014 now, might signal to and that, in turn, could affect consumer confidence, consumer spending, and the ability to create a self-sustaining economic recovery at some point.
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: Is there a risk of this?
Speaker: PETER BARNES.

Sentences: Well, whenever the Fed takes a policy action, there’s always some potential for a signal.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I mean, that’s true not just in these current times, but anytime the Fed lowers or increases interest rates, and that’s something we have to think about.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But I think, generally speaking, that those considerations are outweighed by the need to maintain accommodative financial conditions so that it’s attractive to firms to invest and hire, attractive for those who are eligible to buy homes, and so on, and I think that that ultimately is more powerful than the signal from the change in policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: In particular, the markets and the news media are very good at picking up the underlying economic data and making assessments of the state of the economy and reporting what different people think about the economy, so I wouldn’t overstate the Fed’s ability to massively change expectations through its statements, for example.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, again, I think that while we certainly take that into account, we think it’s important for us to say what we think, and we think it’s important for us to provide the right amount of stimulus to try to help our economy recover from its currently underutilized condition.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Darren Gersh, Nightly Business Report.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: Let me kind of follow up on Peter’s question.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: Why shouldn’t somebody looking at these numbers from the outside say “Look, as aggressive as you say you’ve been, and as aggressive as you have been, it doesn’t look like you’re meeting any of your goals for the next three years on the economy, so why isn’t the Fed doing more now?”  CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: Well, again, as I said earlier, the Fed has been doing a great deal.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: Just since August we have put a date on our expected period of low interest rates.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: We further extension of the expected period of low rates.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: By issuing this expected policy rate information, we hope to convey to the market the extent to which there is support on the Committee for maintaining rates at a low level for a significant time.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: So, you know, I don’t accept the premise that we’ve been passive; we’ve been actually quite active in our policy, and in one respect, the low level of inflation is a validation in the following sense, that there were some who were very concerned that our balance sheet policies and the like would lead to high inflation.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: There’s certainly no sign of that yet, and it hasn’t shown up either in financial markets or in outside forecasters’ expectations.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: Now that being said, as I mentioned earlier, if the situation continues, with inflation below target and unemployment declining at a rate which is very, very slow, then more—our framework, the logic of our framework, says we should be looking for ways to do more.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: It’s not completely straightforward because, of course, we’re now dealing with a variety of nonstandard policy tools—we can’t just lower the federal funds rate 25 basis points like in the good old days—but your basic point is right, that, you know, we need to adopt policies that will both achieve our inflation objectives and help the economy recover as quickly as is feasible.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: And, I would say that your question—actually, an earlier question—shows a benefit of explaining this framework because the framework makes very clear that we need to be thinking about ways in which we can provide further stimulus if we don’t get some improvement in the pace of recovery and a normalization of inflation.
Speaker: DARREN GERSH.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, Patrick Welter from the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung.
Speaker: PATRICK WELTER.

Sentences: I have two short questions.
Speaker: PATRICK WELTER.

Sentences: Your predecessor, Mr. Greenspan, once said about his personal inflation—long-term inflation goal that it would be 0 percent if appropriately measured.
Speaker: PATRICK WELTER.

Sentences: And I would like you to compare the inflation goal you told us about today with that statement.
Speaker: PATRICK WELTER.

Sentences: kind of inflation targeters like the central bank of Sweden or Norway, or are you approaching more the European Central Bank, for example, which has some kind of inflation goal but is not really an inflation targeter?
Speaker: PATRICK WELTER.

Sentences: Excellent questions.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, a literal reading of price stability would say inflation should be at zero.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Now, there are some technical reasons why that may not be true.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: There are probably some measurement biases and other issues that mean that a measured value of inflation above zero is probably consistent with stable prices.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But as we’ve talked about frequently, we set inflation—our inflation objective in a way that was consistent with both sides of the mandate:  price stability—and 2 percent is low enough that we believe that it’s not going to extensively interfere with financial planning and economic planning on the part of households and businesses—but also in the interest of employment.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: A target for inflation that was zero would have several consequences.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: First, we would be spending maybe half of our time, or at least a significant amount of our time, in a deflationary zone.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And we’ve seen in many instances that deflation can be bad for economic performance and bad for employment, and, therefore, setting an inflation target at zero would be not consistent with the other part of our mandate.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Incidentally, related to that, a zero inflation rate would mean that nominal interest rates would be at very low levels, typically 2 to 3 percent or whatever they might be, and that would increase the risk and probability that we would be in a situation like today where we really can’t cut the short-term interest rate any further.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So I think there are good reasons from a dual-mandate perspective to have inflation greater than 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And I would add that, you know, if you look at central banks around the world, whether they are use; the ECB, many other central banks either use 2 percent or a range around 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So this is not at all different from what many other central banks do.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Now, are we inflation targeters?
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: If by “inflation targeter” you mean a central bank that puts top priority on inflation and other goals, like employment, as subsidiary goals, then the answer is no.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: We are a dual-mandate central bank:  We put equal weight on price stability and maximum employment; those are the goals given to us by the Congress.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And so, in that respect, as I mentioned earlier, I think, to Greg, we’re not absolutists:  If there’s a need to let inflation return a little bit more slowly to target in order to get a better result in employment, then that’s something that we would be willing to do.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Having said all that, I think it’s worth noting that even banks that—central banks that call themselves inflation targeters typically pay at least some attention to other parts of the economy:  employment, growth, financial stability, and the like.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So I don’t think there’s really any central bank, or very few, at least, that focus only on inflation.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But again, in terms of terminology, I guess I would reject that term for the Federal Reserve because we are going to be evenhanded in treating the price stability and maximum employment parts of our mandate on a level footing.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: Zach Goldfarb from the Washington Post.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: Two questions.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: First, can you clarify whether if actual economic conditions match their projections, that’s an acceptable future course, or that would require additional easing?
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: And secondly, in the past, a number of times you said that even when interest rates are at the zero bound, the Fed can still have a significant impact on influencing economic growth; do you still believe that the Fed has the capacity to deploy tools that would have a significant impact on bringing down CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: On the first question, I, you know—as was pointed out by Steve, for example—we’ve had some good data recently.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: I think there’s some uncertainty about where the economy is going, and we want to continue to observe how the economy is developing.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: But I would say that, as I’ve said on several—in several answers, that if recovery continues to be modest and progress on unemployment very slow, and if inflation appears to be likely to be below target for a number of years out—so the configuration we’re talking about in the projections—then I think there would be a very strong case, based on our framework, for finding a different—additional tools for expansionary policies or to support the economy.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: So we’ll continue to look at the different options and try to decide what might be most effective.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: We are in a difficult situation in terms of the effectiveness of policy tools.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: My own view, thinking about the effects, for example, of additional purchases—additional securities purchases, I’ve been pretty satisfied in the sense that—in the following sense, that purchases do seem to have the desired effects on financial conditions:  They tend to ease financial conditions, they tend to lower interest rates, they tend to strengthen asset prices.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: And those are exactly the kinds of things that monetary policy normally does in order to try to provide stableness to the economy.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: What has been a bit more uncertain is the effectiveness of the transmission mechanism.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: And we have seen some developments in the economy that have probably weakened the effectiveness of policy, including, notably, the housing sector, where one would expect—with mortgage rates below 4 percent, one would expect to see more activity than we’ve been seeing.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: And the problems in housing finance and so on are part of the reason that the expansionary stimulus is not feeding through as much as we would like to the real economy.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: I would not say, though, that further analyze and study those tools and try to make comparisons in terms of effectiveness, risks, and the like.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: So I think we still have a process to figure out what is the most effective approach.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: Does that—yeah, okay.
Speaker: ZACHARY GOLDFARB.

Sentences: Steve Beckner, Market News International, Mr. Chairman, with a question about the new forward guidance language in the statement itself.
Speaker: STEVE BECKNER.

Sentences: And Peter anticipated one of my questions about the potential danger of it sending a negative signal, but let me ask, What was the rationale for continuing to have forward guidance phraseology instead of just letting these forecasts, these new forecasts of the funds rates, speak for themselves?
Speaker: STEVE BECKNER.

Sentences: No, that’s a very good question.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I might have commented on Zach’s question that our two main tools at this point—given that short-term interest rates are close to zero—are asset purchases, but the other is communications.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And to the extent that we can communicate that rates will be lower for longer, that will ease financial conditions and be a way that we can affect the state of the economy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And that’s part of the reason—other than just a general desire for transparency—that we brought out some of these ideas at this point.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The reason that we just don’t release the economic projections and leave it at that is because, while the economic projections of future policy rates are an important input to our policy discussions around the table, the decision ultimately is made by the Federal Open Market Committee, you know, which is the voters sitting around the table, and in a process by which we exchange ideas and make arguments and come to a collective determination.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, you know, we don’t set the federal funds interest rate by having members send in their vote and not having a meeting; we have a meeting for a reason, which is to talk to each other and try to come to some kind of rates, but clearly, because the participants and the people around the table are the same, the projections should give significant information about where the FOMC is likely to go.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Hugues Honoré with Agence France-Presse.
Speaker: HUGUES HONORÉ.

Sentences: The FOMC stated that global growth has slowed and, of course, that is weighing on financial conditions in the U.S.  Arguably, one way that the Federal Reserve could help would be by extending a loan to the International Monetary Fund.
Speaker: HUGUES HONORÉ.

Sentences: There have been other central banks that have been doing that when the government was reluctant to do so, and we have all noted that the Fed was not shy when it came to extending loans to international financial institutions, private banks, and so on that are based or that have subsidiaries in the U.S.  Is it something that you could consider if the sovereign debt crisis got worse?
Speaker: HUGUES HONORÉ.

Sentences: Well, lending to financial institutions is part of our mandated function; it’s part of our raison d’être to provide a lender of last resort in the case of a panic, as we’ve done in the recent crisis.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Committing funds to the IMF I don’t think is within the purview of the Federal Reserve.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That’s a decision that’s made in the first instance by the Treasury and the Administration and in the second instance via approval through the Congress.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So I think the appropriate deciders in that case would be the Administration and the Congress, not the Federal Reserve.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Scott Spoerry, sir, from CNN.
Speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY.

Sentences: My head’s full of questions, but I’m going to try and limit it to two related questions.
Speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY.

Sentences: You’re linking your inflation target of 2 percent to the PCE.
Speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY.

Sentences: The PCE is something that hundreds of millions of Americans have no idea what it is; they do know what the CPI is.
Speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY.

Sentences: Can you explain, in layman’s terms, something that regular folks might understand, why they should not worry too much when inflation by and to the targeting because the Fed’s always been a little bit vague in terms of what sort of inflation it would accept, and this is a marked change.
Speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY.

Sentences: Because criticism of the Federal Reserve—criticism of you, but the institution itself has been so intense this year because it’s a political year—there are people out there who are going to say “The Federal Reserve has finally just admitted it.
Speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY.

Sentences: Their policy is to destroy 2 percent of the value of my dollars every year.”  How are you going to respond to those people?
Speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY.

Sentences: And also, could you answer the question about the CPI and the PCE?
Speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY.

Sentences: Sure.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Well, we chose the PCE index for some, I think, very valid technical reasons.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: It better allows—better accounts for changes in people’s purchasing patterns; you know, when some things become more expensive, people will tend to move to other types of goods and services.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That’s not accounted for by the CPI, which has fixed weights.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: It also—the PCE—I think more relevant to the average person, the PCE includes all health-care costs, not just out-of-pocket costs, and that has two benefits.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: One is, it reduces the share of the inflation index which is tied to housing.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And the CPI has a very large share devoted to housing, and a large share of that part of the index is imputed—that is, essentially made-up numbers.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So that’s one benefit, to keep the—you know, not to put too much weight on the imputed housing numbers, which is part of the CPI.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: The other is that, even if people are not paying for health care immediately out-of-pocket, they do pay for it, either through taxes or through reduced wages as, you know, increased health-care costs raise insurance premiums for employers.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So I think this is probably a better measure of the inflation that’s faced by typical consumers than the CPI is.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That being said, these various measures—the CPI and others, PCE index and others—move very closely together, and you’re not going to have a situation where the CPI is 10 percent and the closely together.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: So, in that respect, I think if people look at the CPI, they should feel pretty comfortable that, you know, that’s going to be very close to where the PCE inflation is.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: On the 2 percent, again, that’s where the United States has been for many years.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: That’s where most central banks are around the world.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: There’s a very good reason for it, which is to avoid deflation, which is very negative.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I think the argument that, you know, the value of your dollar declines at 2 percent a year is just not really a very good one, unless you’re one of those people who does their lifetime saving in the mattress.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Most people invest in various kinds of instruments, receiving a rate of interest.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And now, it’s true, as has been pointed out, that for the moment interest rates are pretty low, but they’re still positive.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But over a longer period of time, if you—even if you have money in a CD or some other investment vehicle, the interest rate will compensate you for inflation.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: I mean, the two will be tied together.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: And so there really shouldn’t be, you know—at levels of inflation this low, interest rates should pretty much fully compensate for the losses to savers.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: But I would reiterate that we are not unaware of the problems that low interest rates cause for savers, cause for pension fund contributions, insurance companies, and other parts of the economy, and we do try to take that into account as we think about other ramifications of our policy.
Speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

Sentences: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: Peter Cook of Bloomberg Television.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: Two questions, if I could, separate from your role here as Fed Chairman.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: Two issues in Congress right now, on which your advice might be worthwhile.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: The payroll tax cut is coming up for debate again, this debate about whether to extend it for a full year.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: What is your assessment right now of the impact that would have on the U.S. economy if it was not extended?
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: And likewise, what if the Congress were to not implement the 1.2 on automatic spending cuts imposed by the CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: Well, as you know, the Federal Reserve makes it a policy to try to avoid commenting on specific individual tax and spending programs, and I don’t have those numbers at hand in any case.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: But what I would say is the following—is that what I’ve tried to convey to Congress, and I think many other economists have taken the same view, is that responsible fiscal policy has at least two components at this point.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: One is, of course, importantly, to achieve fiscal sustainability.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: And to achieve fiscal sustainability over a long period of time, we need to be acting soon—now would be preferable—to making credible commitments to reducing spending, to improving our programs, to modifying or simplifying our tax code, and so on, so as the ways that will be persuasive to the markets or to the public that over the longer term, over the next 10, 20, 30 years, that our fiscal position will be sustainable.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: So that’s an important thing to do.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: It relates to the second part of your question.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: I think it’s important to take steps at least to—again, the specific steps are up to Congress, but it’s important that action be taken to provide a credible plan to achieve fiscal sustainability.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: The second part of my recommendation, though, is that we need at this juncture to be sensitive to the effects of whatever policy decisions are made on what is still a very fragile recovery.
Speaker: PETER COOK.

Sentences: Again, there are many ways to do that, but I think that should be taken into account as people are looking at policy alternatives in terms of taxes or spending.
Speaker: PETER COOK.
